Stars: Leila Hyams, Conrad Nagel, Bessie Love
Director: William C. de Mille

Released by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and directed by William C. de Mille, this early sound-era romantic comedy explores class clashes and love across social divides. Starring Conrad Nagel as a wealthy, soft-spoken businessman who falls for his secretary, played by Leila Hyams, the story explores the culture shock that ensues when he attempts to integrate into her working-class family.

The film cleverly mixes wit and warmth as the idealistic couple confronts everything from dinner table debates to deep-rooted resentments between economic worlds. Bessie Love adds charm and comedic spark as Hyams‚Äô spirited sister, while character actor Edward J. Nugent rounds out the ensemble with energy and timing.

With dialogue-driven scenes and domestic settings, the film highlights the novelty of early talking pictures while capturing the shifting attitudes of post‚ÄìRoaring Twenties America. Released just as the Great Depression began, the story takes on added resonance as it questions privilege, practicality, and whether love can really bridge the wealth gap.
